awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: An Experimental Study of Confirmation Bias
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans have proven to be far from objective when they assimilate information. As various media and social media platforms have become deeply integrated within our everyday lives, it has become more important than ever to understand how people truly react to new information. Confirmation bias refers to the biased treatment of evidence in favor of a certain hypothesis, and plays an influential role in people’s information interpretation process. However, confirmation bias is not fully understood as recent empirical research have produced mixed evidence in regard to how confirmation bias is triggered and how it affects people’s beliefs. This study will investigate, and provide more insight into, how confirmation bias affects individuals’ abilities to update their beliefs about probabilistic events when they are presented with information. The results from this study will help policymakers design optimal policies that aid people in forming correct beliefs, and prevent information sources from manipulating people’s beliefs. 


There are two forms of confirmation bias: motivated confirmation bias, which refers to the biased treatment of information that is motivated by underlying preferences, and unmotivated confirmation bias, which refers to the biased treatment of information that arises simply because the individual believes her hypothesis is more likely to be true than alternative ones. This study will be among the first to utilize a controlled lab experiment to separately identify, and examine the potential relationship and interactions between the two forms of confirmation bias. Identification of the biases lies within eliciting experimental subjects’ beliefs about probabilistic events, incentivized with a binary scoring rule, and measuring their deviations from the Bayesian posterior beliefs. Separation of the two forms of confirmation bias relies on varying the treatment variable that is motivation. This study connects two topics that have attracted growing attention – confirmation bias and motivated reasoning. Additionally, this study will test the validity of a new theory-based framework for analyzing confirmation bias.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main outcome of this award is a research paper, which also served as an integral part of the Co-PI’s doctoral dissertation, documenting evidence for the simultaneous existence of two biases of different origin that may influence a person’s beliefs. The data used in this research comes from a lab experiment of approximately 200 subjects and, additionally, some online sessions with around 700 subjects, all funded by this award. The preliminary results were presented at a conference, and the research paper is currently being prepared for journal submission.

Previous research has shown that people’s beliefs and judgements may be biased by either their preferences or their prior attitudes. This research provides positive evidence that both forms of bias can be present simultaneously, but they act independently. This project connects two topics within the field that had hardly been discussed together, shedding light on their relationship and providing guidance for future research. On a broader scale, people’s beliefs play a crucial role in nearly every aspect of life, including economic decisions, interactions on social media, political inclinations, etc. The deeper understanding of the biases that affect people’s beliefs may help us analyze the dynamics of changing beliefs, as well as provide recommendations for policies, especially when dealing with polarized and extreme beliefs. More specifically, that the two biases discussed in this project may occur simultaneously implies that one must be cautious in identifying the exact source of a belief bias. Their independence implies that one may implement policies that target one bias without worrying about the other.
